text: Here at Growy, we are growing
microgreens and herbs

and our main challenge is to produce
tasty, affordable,
high-end nutrients products.

And we think we can do that
by fully automating and robotizing
our vertical farm.

Everything that robot needs to do
is orchestrated from our AWS services.

We ask the robots to go water
the plants three times a day,

we move our plants in our farm
with robots,

and all these activities we do
without human intervention.
So to run vertical farms, it's necessary

that we lean on our information
to see how the state of the farm is.

We collect about a 100,000 data points
on one growth cycle.

And we take about 1,000
plus photos of this growth cycle.

And, in our current farm
here, we run about

500 growth cycles
currently in concurrency.

It's undoable for a human
to look at every picture.

But if you look at the Amazon services
for image recognition,

we can run multiple of thousands of images
of these plants to the system.
At AWS, we have two main elements.

The first one is a plant
manager, and in plant manager
we instruct all our robots.

And the second platform we have,
is our data collection account.

And there, we extract all information
from our farm and from the robots,

and we conduct our analytics
and our dashboarding.

Starting out, AWS made that we could start
developing quite fast.

We started about one and a half years ago
with like six developers.

At in the beginning of next year,
we'll build 1-3 new farms
with 200+ robots and
400 camera devices.
